### Pre-requisites

This text builds on all the concepts presented in the previous texts. Additionally, we will use the concepts of counting and scales discussed in the first two chapters of the "*First steps*" and expands on the concepts presented in the "*Atlas*" section

### Introduction

In the previous texts, we analyzed why there is no evidence of a global deluge. Among the reasons discussed were the principle of mass conservation and evidence that dry regions inhabited by people have always existed, ruling out the possibility of a worldwide flood

The absence of a global event, however, does not exclude the occurrence of multiple local floods. Many of these events were later dramatized and amplified by great writers who, through the use of literary devices, transformed real events into monumental narratives.

To conclude this series on understanding texts related to floods and deluges, we will explore events highlighted by Andreas N. Angelakis and other researchers, as well as studies by *National Geographic*. These works confirm the occurrence of significant floods in the past and demonstrate that similar phenomena continue to occur today

### Floods Through Time

The work of Andreas N. Angelakis and his collaborators provides valuable insights into flooding events that are not widely known but hold significant importance. Their conclusions are supported by data from various historical periods. As Angelakis and his team state

The *National Geographic* documentary also references events in the Black Sea region as a possible origin for the flood narratives of Northern peoples. However, this is not the sole focus of their discussion. Additionally, the "Mega El Ni√±o" phenomenon, which caused massive flooding and may have significantly impacted ancient civilizations in the Americas, such as the Chim√∫, continues to influence the world today

While this summary does not include all the flooding events mentioned in Angelakis‚Äôs work or other referenced research, a more detailed analysis of these sources is recommended for further insights. Nevertheless, it is essential to emphasize that no evidence of a global flood was found.

### Reminder

This is the fourth text in the series dedicated to the interpretation of ancient texts about floods and deluges. Before concluding, let's review some key points.

We began our study by analyzing the concepts of "world" and "sky" in Mesopotamian cultures and how the lack of understanding of the surrounding environment may have led to the idea of an extraordinarily long lifespan, incompatible with human nature
Since we are dealing with floods and deluges, we explored the water cycle and the law of conservation of mass. With this, we discussed how the concept of "world" in Mesopotamia differs from our own

After grasping these initial concepts, we examined the epics of *Gilgamesh* and *Atrahasis*, as well as the Sumerian deluge narratives. Within them, we identified a recurring narrative pattern: a few people and animals are saved in a boat, described in various shapes (cubic or circular), following a divine punishment. From this, we established the probable periods in which these deluges occurred and compared them with data from other regions, concluding that there were no global floods

We concluded our study with an analysis of two different papers that mapped floods across the world at various times, providing context for the conditions under which Mediterranean authors wrote their texts.

### Conclusion

We are concluding the first chapter, in which we observed the presence of mathematics in ancient texts. In addition, we explored topics related to language, which ultimately allowed us to study various ancient narratives about floods and deluges.

exercise_v2.question: Was there a flood or deluge?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Floods are common but extraordinary events. When we live near waterways such as rivers, any change in their intensity can result in flooding which, depending on the magnitude of the destruction, may be perceived as deluges.

exercise_v2.question: Did we confirm everything written in the ancient texts?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Based on the currently available data, we observed that many ancient texts employ figures of speech. Thus, it is possible that they described local events in a way that, through the use of these rhetorical devices, transformed them into monumental occurrences, giving the impression they affected larger regions that, in reality, were never impacted. On the other hand, it is also possible that these texts were inspired by significant local disasters, grounded in real events, that left a profound impact on the societies of the time.
